P2: I’m a dancer whose career depends on physical precision, but agonizing migraines strike unpredictably. I track medication dosages and aura patterns in excruciating detail, but when asked about stress triggers, I say ‘it’s just biology.’
conversation:
Therapist: Before we dive in, how are you feeling about being here today and exploring your thoughts and feelings in this session?
Patient: Honestly, I'm a bit anxious about being here, I guess I've always seen therapy as a last resort, but my migraines have been getting worse, so I feel like I'm out of options. I just want to figure out how to get my career back on track.
Therapist: It sounds like your motivation for seeking help is driven more by the impact of your migraines on your career, rather than a desire to explore the underlying causes of your struggles. Can you tell me more about what's at stake for you in getting your career back on track?
Patient: I'd hate to lose my spot in the company, I've worked too hard to get to this point and I'm not sure I can afford to take time off to try and figure out what's going on with my migraines.
Therapist: That sense of urgency and fear of losing your current position suggests there may be a deep-seated fear of failure or loss of identity tied to your career. Can you help me understand what specifically would happen if you were to lose your job or take time off - what are the fears and thoughts that come up for you?
Patient: I'd lose my sense of purpose and identity, I've been a dancer my whole life and it's hard to imagine doing anything else. My parents invested a lot in my training, and I feel like I'd be letting them down if I'm not successful.
Therapist: It sounds like your identity is deeply intertwined with being a dancer, and the thought of not being able to pursue it professionally is tied to feelings of shame and not living up to your parents' expectations. Can you think of any moments from your past when you first started dancing that might have contributed to this sense of identity tied to your profession?
Patient: I remember my mom taking me to see ballet performances when I was a kid and how she'd beam with pride, telling everyone I was going to be a famous dancer one day - it was always about being the best, and I think that pressure stuck with me. Looking back, it's like I've been trying to live up to this ideal my whole life, even when it feels suffocating.
Therapist: It sounds like your mother's expectation of you becoming a famous dancer created a sense of conditional love and validation, where your worth was tied to achieving a certain goal. How do you think that dynamic has played out in your relationships throughout your life, particularly in your relationship with your mother, and how has that impacted your sense of self-worth?
Patient: It's funny, even now as an adult, I still feel like I'm performing for my mom, trying to prove to her that I'm worthy of her love and attention, rather than being myself. I've been trying to 'get it right' for so long that I've lost touch with what I truly want, and it's hard to shake the feeling that I'm just going through the motions.
Therapist: It sounds like this dynamic with your mother has created a sense of disconnection from your own desires and needs, and now you're wondering if your pursuit of a career in dance was more about pleasing her than truly following your own passion. Can you explore with me what it would take for you to start letting go of this need for external validation and instead trust that you're worthy of love and respect regardless of your professional success?
Patient: I think that's a huge part of why I've been so resistant to exploring my migraines as a source of stress - it's like admitting that I'm not in control, and that my body is somehow failing me, which feels deeply connected to my fear of disappointing my mom. But what if I'm not failing, and my body is just trying to tell me something about how I'm living my life?
Therapist: That's a fascinating insight - the idea that your body's symptoms could be a message from within, rather than a sign of weakness or failure, is a powerful one. Can you imagine what it would take for you to start tuning in to your body's wisdom, rather than trying to push through or deny its signals, and what that might mean for your relationship with your migraines?
Patient: It feels like I've been in this pattern of trying to control everything, including my body, and maybe it's time for me to learn to surrender to my own needs and listen to what my body is trying to tell me. I'm scared to let go of the sense of control, but I'm also tired of feeling like I'm living on autopilot and ignoring my own well-being.
Therapist: Let's explore this idea of surrender further: what would be the first step you could take to start listening to your body and acknowledging its needs, rather than trying to push through or control it?
Patient: I think one small step I could take is to start paying more attention to the early signs of a migraine, like a slight change in my vision or a sense of tension in my neck, and taking breaks to stretch or rest when I feel those sensations, rather than trying to push through and risk a full-blown attack. Maybe by acknowledging and respecting my body's early warnings, I can start to develop a more trusting relationship with it, rather than constantly being on high alert for when something goes wrong.
Therapist: That's a great first step in developing a more trusting relationship with your body - acknowledging and respecting its early warnings can be a powerful way to build a sense of trust and agency over your physical well-being. What do you think would be the most challenging part of taking breaks and resting when you feel those early signs of a migraine, and how might you plan to navigate that challenge?
Patient: I think the hardest part would be feeling like I'm being lazy or letting my team down, even though I know it's necessary for my health, and I'd have to remind myself that it's okay to prioritize my own needs and that my absence won't define my worth as a dancer. I'd try to reframe taking breaks as a proactive step to maintain my physical and mental well-being, rather than a sign of weakness.
Therapist: It's interesting that you mention feeling like you're being lazy when you take breaks, as that brings up the idea that you've internalized this notion of hard work and productivity as a measure of your worth, rather than recognizing your worth as an inherent aspect of your being. How do you think your sense of self-worth would shift if you were to reframe your identity as a dancer from one that's solely defined by your professional success to one that encompasses your inherent value and worth as a person?
Patient: I think that's the key to breaking free from this cycle of self-doubt and pressure - recognizing that my worth isn't defined by my accomplishments, but by who I am as a person. It's funny, I never thought about it before, but what if I'm already enough, no matter what my career looks like?

P2: I was mercilessly bullied two years ago. Now I dread the hallway, hyper-alert for whispers and laughter. I text my answers in session or look down at my phone. If asked to describe feelings, I reply with one-word texts: ‘fine,’ ‘okay.’
conversation:
Therapist: How have you found this online therapy experience so far, is it meeting your expectations or are there any challenges you've encountered?
Patient: I'm still getting used to it, to be honest. It's weird not having face-to-face interaction, but I guess it's a good way to open up more easily.
Therapist: You mention that you're finding it easier to open up online, which could suggest that you're more comfortable sharing thoughts and feelings when you're not in the same physical space as me - can you tell me more about what you think is behind that?
Patient: It feels safer, I think, like I can control the pace and distance a bit more, which is kind of a comfort for me. It helps me avoid eye contact, which can be overwhelming.
Therapist: It sounds like avoiding eye contact is an important aspect of your comfort in this online space, could you help me understand what happens when you do feel overwhelmed by eye contact in person, do you feel like you're unable to think or process your emotions effectively in those moments?
Patient: It makes me feel trapped, like I'm under a microscope, like everyone's watching me and judging me all at once. My mind goes blank, and I get this knot in my stomach.
Therapist: That sounds incredibly overwhelming and anxiety-provoking, it's no wonder you're drawn to this online space where you can maintain more control over your interactions. Can you think of a situation or a specific person from your past where you felt particularly judged or scrutinized, and how did that experience shape your current behavior around eye contact?
Patient: It was the girl who led the group bullying me in middle school, Emily. She'd stare me down in class and make snide comments, always with this condescending smile that made me feel like I was the joke.
Therapist: That must have been a deeply painful experience, and I can see how it could have had a lasting impact on your comfort with eye contact and feelings of vulnerability in social situations. Can you tell me, do you think that Emily's behavior towards you was somehow a reflection of her own struggles or insecurities, or did it feel more like she was simply trying to exert power over you?
Patient: It felt like she was trying to assert power over me, like she took pleasure in making me feel small and weak, and it's like that feeling has stuck with me. It's hard for me to think she was struggling with her own insecurities, it feels like an excuse.
Therapist: I'd like to gently challenge your assumption that Emily's behavior was solely about exerting power over you, rather than struggling with her own insecurities, could it be that you've been carrying around a sense of responsibility for her behavior and feelings, rather than recognizing her own agency in it? How might this dynamic be playing out in your relationships today, where you may be more likely to people-please or avoid conflict to avoid being seen as weak or vulnerable?
Patient: I don't know, I guess I never thought about it that way, but now that you mention it, I do tend to avoid conflict and go along with what others want to do, it's just easier that way. It's hard to admit, but I feel like I'm constantly trying to be invisible.
Therapist: That's a significant insight, and it sounds like this pattern of people-pleasing may be a coping mechanism that's helped you avoid feelings of vulnerability, but also may be limiting your ability to express yourself authentically and set healthy boundaries in your relationships - can you imagine what it might be like to start small and take a risk in a low-stakes situation, like asserting your own opinion in a conversation with a friend?
Patient: I guess it's hard for me to imagine taking that risk, but I think I'd be anxious about being rejected or seen as disagreeable. It's like I'm already anticipating the worst-case scenario.
Therapist: Let's explore this idea of anticipating the worst-case scenario, can you tell me, do you think this anticipatory anxiety is a way of protecting yourself from the potential rejection, or is it also a way of avoiding the anxiety you felt when you were bullied, and the shame that came with it?
Patient: I think it's a mix of both, the rejection and the shame from the past are tied together in my mind, and the anticipation of feeling that way again is what keeps me stuck. It's like my brain is constantly scanning for potential threats, waiting for the other shoe to drop.
Therapist: It sounds like your brain has become an expert at predicting worst-case scenarios as a way of trying to prevent the pain of rejection and shame, but in doing so, you're actually perpetuating a cycle of anxiety and avoidance - can you imagine what it might be like to approach relationships and interactions with a sense of curiosity and openness, rather than anticipation of danger?
Patient: I guess it's scary to think about being open and curious because it feels like I'd be leaving myself vulnerable to getting hurt again, but at the same time, I don't want to be controlled by fear of what might happen. It's like I'm stuck in this constant tug-of-war between wanting to be safe and wanting to be myself.
Therapist: It sounds like you're caught between a desire for safety and a desire for authenticity, and I'm curious, what would happen if you were to take a small step towards exploring this sense of curiosity and openness, rather than trying to predict the outcome? For example, can you think of a situation in your daily life where you could take a tiny risk and engage with someone or a situation with a sense of genuine interest, rather than trying to anticipate how they might react?
Patient: I'm not sure, but I've been trying to think about it and I guess I could try engaging in a conversation with my coworker who always asks me about my weekends, but I usually just give a brief answer and change the subject because I'm too nervous to talk about myself. It's just that I feel like she's always listening so intently and I don't want to feel like I'm being put on the spot.

P2: I’m expecting my first child and can’t stop worrying about every possible complication. I arrive with hospital-bag checklists and birth-plan spreadsheets, and I deflect when invited to share how the anxiety feels inside.
conversation:
Therapist: Before we begin, how are you feeling about being here today and exploring your concerns in a safe and non-judgmental space? What brings you to therapy at this time, and what are your hopes for our work together?
Patient: "I'm a bit nervous, I guess, but I feel like I really need to talk about this stuff before the baby arrives, so I can feel more prepared. I just want to be a good parent and make sure everything goes smoothly, I suppose."
Therapist: Can you tell me more about what you mean by "this stuff" that you want to talk about before the baby arrives? What specific concerns or worries are you holding onto that you feel need to be addressed before becoming a parent?
Patient: I guess it's just all the little things that could go wrong - the baby's birth weight, delivery method, potential health issues... anything that could impact their well-being, really. I've been reading so much online and talking to other moms, and it's hard not to imagine every worst-case scenario.
Therapist: It sounds like you're putting a lot of emphasis on control and preparation, which is understandable given the significant life change that's ahead of you. Can you think of a time in your life when you felt a sense of control over a situation, and how that experience might inform your approach to parenthood?
Patient: I actually excelled in college by making detailed study plans and to-do lists, so I guess that's where I learned to feel more in control of my environment, but even with all those plans, I still had moments of uncertainty and anxiety. It didn't really make me feel better, but it made me feel like I was doing something about it, I suppose.
Therapist: It's interesting that you mention making detailed plans and to-do lists in college as a way to cope with uncertainty - can you see how that same approach might be translating into your preparations for parenthood, and potentially creating more anxiety rather than alleviating it? How might trying a different approach, one that allows for more flexibility and uncertainty, feel to you?
Patient: I think about how I used to feel like I was drowning in my college plans, always thinking about what I needed to do next, and I worry that I'll feel the same way with the baby, except instead of studying for exams, it'll be worrying about every little thing. That thought is actually kind of terrifying to me.
Therapist: Let's explore this idea of being overwhelmed by constant planning further - are there any specific emotions or thoughts that arise when you imagine yourself in this scenario, worrying about every little thing related to the baby's care? What do you think would happen if you were to intentionally let go of some of that planning and control, even if just for a small part of the day?
Patient: It's hard to imagine stopping the planning and preparation entirely, because it feels like if I'm not constantly anticipating and preparing for every possibility, I'll be caught off guard and the baby will suffer somehow. But at the same time, thinking about what would happen if I did let go of some of that control is kind of... liberating, I suppose.
Therapist: Can you think of a moment recently, even if it's a small one, where you've had to let go of control or perfection in a situation, like taking a break from planning, and how did you feel in that moment? How did the outcome compare to your initial expectations?
Patient: I remember the other day, I had to let my partner take over cooking dinner when I was running late and I was worried it wouldn't turn out right, but it ended up being fine and I was actually really proud of him for handling it. It was a small moment, but it showed me that things don't always go as planned, and that's okay.
Therapist: That's a great example of letting go of control and trusting someone else to handle a situation - what if you were to extend that same trust to yourself, allowing yourself to be present and adapt to the unexpected moments that will inevitably arise with parenthood, rather than trying to micromanage every detail?
Patient: I think I've been so focused on preparing for every potential outcome that I've forgotten how to just be present in the moment, and I wonder if that's something I could work on learning again. It's a scary thought, but maybe allowing myself to be present and adaptable will actually make me a more capable and confident parent in the long run.
Therapist: Let's explore this idea of reclaiming your presence in the moment - can you think of a small, low-stakes situation, like taking a walk or having a cup of coffee, where you can intentionally focus on being fully engaged in that moment, without any pressure or expectation of outcomes, and what might that feel like?
Patient: I think taking a walk in the park with my partner could be a good starting point, just focusing on the sights, sounds, and smells around us, and letting go of any thoughts about what I need to do next or what I should be thinking about. I feel like it's a small step towards being more present, and it might help me build up the courage to be more present with the baby when they arrive.
Therapist: Let's explore this idea of small, low-stakes moments as a way to build up to more significant situations, like parenting - can you think of another activity or situation where you can intentionally let go of control and simply be present, such as a hobby or a creative pursuit? What would be the first steps you'd take to make time for this activity and commit to fully engaging in it?
Patient: I've been meaning to pick up painting again, something I enjoyed doing in high school, but haven't made time for in years - I think committing to setting aside a small block of time each week to paint might help me practice being fully present and letting go of perfection. Maybe just letting myself make a mess and not worrying about the outcome would be a good starting point.
Therapist: I'd like to gently challenge the idea of "letting yourself make a mess" in painting, as it still implies a level of control and expectation - perhaps it's more about embracing the process without attachment to the outcome, rather than letting go of perfection. Can you imagine allowing yourself to create without a specific goal or expectation, and simply see what arises from the experience?
Patient: I think that's a subtle but important distinction - I can see how trying to create without expectations could be a way to truly let go of perfection and just enjoy the process, which is something I've been missing out on. It feels like that could be a really freeing experience, and one that might translate to being more present with the baby too.

P2: I’ve been HIV-positive for 20 years. I take my meds, but I’m terrified of rejection if anyone finds out. I review lab results and adherence logs meticulously, then steer away when asked about intimate relationships or fear of disclosure.
conversation:
Therapist: Can you tell me more about what brings you to therapy at this time, what's been going on that's feeling unbearable or unmanageable for you?
Patient: "It's the constant anxiety that's been building up, I guess. Every date or encounter feels like a ticking time bomb, like I'm just waiting for the other shoe to drop and they'll discover my secret."
Therapist: I sense a deep-seated fear of being discovered and rejected, which seems to be driving this anxiety. Can you tell me more about what this "secret" is that you're keeping, and what specifically do you think others would reject you for?
Patient: "It's not just about rejection, it's the feeling of losing control and being vulnerable in a relationship. I've had too many past experiences where people didn't accept me for who I am, and it's left me with this deep-seated mistrust of others."
Therapist: It sounds like past experiences have left you feeling like you're always on guard, anticipating potential rejection and loss of control in relationships. Can you think of a specific instance from your past that stands out to you as particularly painful or formative in terms of shaping this fear of vulnerability?
Patient: There was this one guy I was seeing a few years ago, and we were getting serious. He would often mention his friends and family, and I felt like I was being pushed to meet them, to be part of their lives, but every time I'd try to bring up my HIV status, he'd change the subject or get defensive.
Therapist: It sounds like this experience was particularly hurtful for you, and it's possible that this feeling of being pushed to hide a part of yourself has created a pattern of self-protection in your relationships, where you're always on the defensive and waiting for others to reject you. Can you tell me more about what went through your mind when you realized this guy was pushing you to keep your HIV status a secret, and how that made you feel about yourself?
Patient: I felt like I was being manipulated and used, like he only wanted me for who I was on the surface, not for the real me, and that realization made me question my own worth and the fact that I'm somehow broken or unlovable because of my status. It also made me think that I'm probably unlovable to anyone else too.
Therapist: It seems like this experience has left you with a profound sense of shame and self-doubt about your worth and lovability, not just in relation to this particular person, but potentially in all relationships. Can you explore with me how you think this shame and self-doubt have contributed to your difficulty with vulnerability and openness in your current relationships?
Patient: "It's like I've become my own worst critic, constantly questioning whether anyone can truly love and accept me for who I am, and I'm terrified to find out if I'm right or not. I've started to wonder if the anxiety is a self-fulfilling prophecy, if I'm inadvertently pushing people away before they even get close enough to find out my secret."
Therapist: You're acknowledging that your anxiety may be a self-fulfilling prophecy, which is a very insightful observation. Can you tell me more about how you think this pattern of self-protection and anticipating rejection has been playing out in your dating life, specifically in terms of how you approach getting to know someone and how quickly you tend to shut down or pull back?
Patient: "It feels like I'm in a constant state of 'testing' potential partners, trying to see if they'll ask the right questions or if they'll push me to be more open, but ultimately, I think I'm just using it as an excuse to avoid getting close to anyone, to avoid the possibility of getting hurt again."
Therapist: Can you help me understand how this self-testing approach of yours has been working out for you so far, in terms of the quality of connections you're making and the depth of intimacy you're experiencing in your relationships? What do you think you'd need to happen for you to feel safe enough to let your guard down and be more authentic in your interactions with others?
Patient: "It feels like I'm stuck in a cycle of self-sabotage, constantly sabotaging potential relationships before they even have a chance to grow, and I'm starting to realize that I'm not just protecting myself from rejection, but also from the possibility of genuine connection and intimacy."
Therapist: I notice that you've been using the phrase "stuck in a cycle of self-sabotage" - what does that phrase mean to you, and what does it feel like to acknowledge being trapped in this pattern? Can you imagine what it would take for you to feel like you're breaking free from this cycle, rather than perpetuating it?
Patient: "It feels like a weight's been lifted off my shoulders to finally acknowledge this pattern, but at the same time, I'm scared of what comes next, like I'm standing at the edge of a cliff, unsure of how to take the first step towards freedom."
Therapist: It sounds like you're experiencing a mix of relief and fear, which is understandable, given the weight of breaking free from a long-standing pattern. Can you explore with me what you think the first step would be for you to take in order to begin moving towards freedom from this cycle of self-sabotage, even if it feels small or uncomfortable?
Patient: "I think the first step for me would be to start small, like acknowledging and accepting my HIV status as a part of myself, rather than a secret to be hidden, even if it's just in front of a trusted friend or a therapist, to practice being open with someone I feel safe with."
Therapist: That's a great starting point, acknowledging and accepting your HIV status as a part of yourself can be a powerful step towards self-acceptance and vulnerability. How do you think you'd approach this process of sharing your status with a trusted friend or me, and what specifically do you think you're afraid might happen or go wrong?
Patient: I'm worried that even with a trusted friend or you, there's still a part of me that's convinced they'll be shocked or uncomfortable, and that this will change the dynamic of our relationship forever. I'm afraid that by sharing my status, I'll be relinquishing control and exposing myself to potential judgment, which is terrifying.

P2: I started cutting last semester because stress became unbearable. Now I feel trapped in the cycle. I show old scars and say ‘it’s under control,’ then refuse permission to discuss my emotions or motivations.
conversation:
Therapist: How have you noticed your emotions shifting throughout the conversation so far today, and what do you think triggered any notable changes?
Patient: I've noticed my emotions shifting from a sense of guardedness to a slight unease, I think it's because you're not pushing me to talk about my scars, but rather exploring my emotional state, which is making me more receptive. Your approach is a bit different from what I'm used to, and it's making me wonder if there's a way out of this cycle.
Therapist: It sounds like you're appreciative of the non-judgmental space I've created, but also possibly ambivalent about confronting your scars. Can you help me understand what you mean by "a way out of this cycle" - what specifically do you hope to achieve or change?
Patient: I'm hoping to break free from this pattern of hiding behind my scars and the guilt that comes with it, and instead, be able to talk about the emotions that drive me to self-harm. I feel like I'm stuck in this perpetual state of shame and self-blame, and I want to learn how to cope with my feelings in a healthier way.
Therapist: It sounds like you're hinting that you're tired of using your scars as a shield to protect yourself from potentially getting hurt, but perhaps also afraid of what you might discover about yourself if you drop the guard, what are you most afraid you might find?
Patient: I'm afraid of confronting the depth of my emotions and the realization that I'm more entrenched in this cycle than I want to admit, which could be a harsh truth to face. It's scary to think that I might discover I'm not as in control as I claim to be.
Therapist: It's interesting that you mention being afraid of discovering you're not in control, but can you think of any situations or periods in your life where you actually felt a sense of control or mastery over your emotions and behaviors, and what were those circumstances?
Patient: I remember a period in high school when I excelled in a passion project, a photography club, where I felt completely absorbed and focused, and for a while, I was able to manage my stress and anxiety through creativity, but that sense of control was short-lived and eventually got derailed when the project's expectations and deadlines piled up. What I'm left with now is this lingering feeling that I was just pretending to be in control back then, and that's even more unsettling than the thought of being out of control now.
Therapist: It seems that even in the moment when you felt a sense of control, you're now questioning whether it was genuine or just a temporary reprieve from the overwhelming feelings you're trying to avoid, suggesting that your self-doubt might be a pervasive pattern in your life. Can you explore what you think would need to happen for you to believe that you are truly in control of your emotions and behaviors, rather than just pretending to be?
Patient: I think I would need to feel a sense of autonomy and agency in my daily life, like I have the freedom to make choices that align with my values and goals, without the weight of shame and self-doubt holding me back. For me, that might mean learning to recognize and honor my emotions, rather than trying to suppress or hide them through self-harm.
Therapist: Can you think of a specific instance where you've been able to make choices that align with your values and goals without feeling held back by shame and self-doubt, and how did that experience feel for you? What do you think would be the first step towards creating more of those moments in your daily life?
Patient: I remember a small moment last semester when I chose to take a mental health day instead of pushing through my assignments, and it felt like a tiny act of defiance against the self-doubt that had been holding me back, and it was liberating. I think the first step towards creating more of those moments would be to start small, like allowing myself to take breaks without feeling guilty or worried about falling behind.
Therapist: It sounds like taking that mental health day was a significant moment of self-care and empowerment for you, but can you think of a situation recently where you felt pressured to hide or minimize your self-care, and what was the cost of that decision? How did you justify to yourself that taking care of your own needs was less important than your obligations or responsibilities?
Patient: Lately, I've been prioritizing academics over my own well-being, telling myself that I need to push through the stress and anxiety in order to get good grades, even when it feels like I'm on the verge of burnout, and that's led to me feeling increasingly resentful and disconnected from my own needs.
Therapist: It seems that you've been conditioned to prioritize others' expectations over your own needs, and that's led to a sense of disconnection from your values and goals, can you explore how you think this pattern started and how it's been maintained over time?
Patient: I think this pattern of prioritizing others' expectations over my own needs started when I was younger, and my parents would often express disappointment if I didn't excel academically, which made me feel like I was only worthy if I was doing well. This expectation has been perpetuated through societal pressure and the fear of not meeting the standards set by my peers.
Therapist: It sounds like you've been carrying this weight of external expectations since childhood, and I'm curious, what do you think would happen if you were to communicate your own needs and boundaries to others, rather than trying to meet their expectations, even if it means not meeting their standards? How do you think your relationships and sense of self-worth would change if you started to prioritize your own needs and desires above others'?
Patient: I think if I started prioritizing my own needs and desires, I'd risk losing the approval and validation of others, but it's a chance for me to discover what truly makes me happy and fulfilled. It's terrifying to imagine being alone in my decisions, but it's also a possibility that could lead to a sense of authenticity and self-acceptance.
Therapist: I'd like to explore this fear of losing approval and validation from others a bit further - can you think of any specific relationships in your life where you've prioritized others' expectations and sacrificed your own needs, and what was the cost of that compromise in terms of your self-worth and relationships?
Patient: I think of my relationship with my best friend, who always pushes me to take on more responsibilities and attend social events, and I often feel like I'm losing myself in the process of trying to meet her expectations, which leaves me feeling drained and resentful. It's hard for me to express my own needs to her because I don't want to risk losing our friendship, but deep down, I feel like I'm just going through the motions to maintain the relationship rather than truly connecting with her.

P2: After my baby was born, intrusive thoughts made me wash bottles dozens of times a day. I read out my cleaning rituals step by step, but protest whenever the therapist suggests tolerating uncertainty or skipping a wash.
conversation:
Therapist: Before we begin, how are you feeling about being here today, and what brings you to therapy at this moment in your life?
Patient: I'm feeling a bit anxious about being here, but at the same time, I'm hoping to finally figure out why I've been stuck in this cycle of constant cleaning. I just want to understand what's driving these thoughts and behaviors.
Therapist: It sounds like there's a sense of urgency and hope mixed with a touch of apprehension in your voice - can you tell me more about what you mean by "stuck in this cycle of constant cleaning"?
Patient: It's like I'm on this never-ending loop, where no matter how clean I make things, I still feel like I need to do more - it's like my mind is constantly questioning whether I've done enough. Every time I stop washing, I feel a knot in my stomach, like I'm waiting for something to go wrong.
Therapist: I notice that you mention a "knot in your stomach" and a sense of impending doom when you stop cleaning - can you help me understand what's going on in that physical sensation, is it a feeling of fear, anxiety, or something else?
Patient: It's hard to describe, but it's more like a sense of dread, like I'm waiting for something to break or contaminate, and I feel like I'm the only one who can prevent it from happening. That's why I keep going back to the bottle or the surface, just to make sure everything is okay.
Therapist: That sense of being the only one who can prevent something from going wrong is quite a heavy burden to carry - can you think of a time when this sense of responsibility wasn't as intense, or when you felt more able to trust that things would be okay even if you didn't intervene?
Patient: To be honest, I don't really remember a time when I didn't feel this way, but I've seen my mom clean obsessively when I was growing up, so maybe that's where it started for me. But even thinking about that now makes me want to go check the sink to make sure it's clean.
Therapist: It sounds like there's a strong connection between your childhood observation of your mother's cleaning habits and your current behavior, and I'm curious, what do you think it is about her behavior that you may have internalized or taken on as your own?
Patient: It's like she was always anxious about things being perfect, and I think I've taken on that pressure to be the one to ensure everything is spotless, to make up for whatever imperfections she felt existed. When I think about it, I feel a surge of guilt for not being able to let things be imperfect, like I'm failing her somehow.
Therapist: As you reflect on taking on this responsibility, I want to gently challenge you - is it possible that by perpetuating this need for perfection, you're inadvertently recreating a sense of connection with your mother, rather than truly breaking free from the pattern you've described? How does the idea of this dynamic between you and your mother sit with you, and what does it bring up for you?
Patient: That's a really uncomfortable idea, it's almost like I'm honoring her by being so meticulous, but at the same time, it's suffocating me. I feel a strong urge to go check the bottle again, just to make sure it's clean.
Therapist: I notice that as we explore this idea, your cleaning impulses seem to be escalating, and you're mentioning an urge to check the bottle again - can you acknowledge that urge and try to hold space for it without acting on it for a moment, and let's see if we can explore the emotions behind it together?
Patient: I feel like I'm on the verge of a panic attack, my mind is racing with all the things that could go wrong if I don't check the bottle right now. If I don't do it, I'll be letting her down, and it's like I'll be abandoning her all over again.
Therapist: It sounds like the idea of abandoning your mother is triggering a deep-seated fear of rejection or abandonment, which is being linked to your cleaning compulsions, and I'd like to explore this dynamic further - can you tell me more about what you imagine happens if you don't meet your mother's expectations in this regard?
Patient: I imagine that she'll be disappointed in me, that she'll feel like I'm not good enough, and that she'll pull away, leaving me feeling like I'm not worthy of love or care. It's like I'm constantly trying to prove myself to her, even though I'm not even sure why it matters.
Therapist: Let's take a moment to acknowledge that it's incredibly brave of you to confront these deeply vulnerable emotions - can you imagine a scenario where you're not trying to prove yourself to your mother, but rather, you're showing yourself kindness and compassion in the face of uncertainty, and how does that feel? What would it mean to prioritize your own needs and well-being in this situation, rather than trying to meet an unattainable ideal of perfection?
Patient: I feel like I'm getting a glimpse of what that might look like, but it's hard to shake the feeling that I'm being selfish, that I'm putting my own needs above my mother's, which feels like a betrayal. P2: I panic if my phone’s battery dips below 10% or if I can’t get data signal during a ride. I discuss battery-saving settings, external chargers, and app caching; but I deflect when asked why I’m so terrified to be offline.
conversation:
Therapist: I'd like to start by acknowledging that it takes a lot of courage to share your concerns with me today, and I'm committed to creating a safe and non-judgmental space for you to explore your thoughts and feelings. Can you tell me what brings you to therapy at this time, and what you hope to work on during our sessions together?
Patient: I guess I just feel really overwhelmed and anxious about certain situations, and I'm hoping we can figure out some ways to manage that together. I'm open to exploring whatever that might entail, as long as it doesn't involve being offline.
Therapist: It sounds like the idea of exploring this further online is important to you, which might suggest that you're feeling anxious about in-person interactions or vulnerability in general. Can you tell me more about what you mean by "being offline" – does that mean avoiding certain situations or people, or is it more about avoiding feelings or emotions that come up in social interactions?
Patient: I think it's more about having access to information and being able to stay connected, like having Google Maps on in the car or knowing I can quickly look up directions. When my phone is dead or can't get a signal, it's just really frustrating, you know?
Therapist: It sounds like you're using technology as a coping mechanism to feel more in control and prepared, which can be very reassuring. However, I'm curious - does this sense of control and preparedness extend to other areas of your life, such as social interactions or making decisions, or is this mainly related to accessing information?
Patient: I think it's just about feeling like I'm missing a crucial tool, you know? I've actually started using a portable charger for when I'm in the car, so I'm not as anxious about running out of battery, but I still get nervous when I'm in a dead zone.
Therapist: It seems like you've found a way to mitigate one source of anxiety, but still experience discomfort in situations where you're unable to access information or technology, which suggests that there may be a deeper sense of reliance on these tools. Can you tell me more about what it feels like to be without your phone or access to information in those moments – is it a feeling of panic or something else?
Patient: I'd rather not think about what it feels like without my phone right now, to be honest. It's just really unsettling to not have that sense of security and ability to problem-solve on demand.
Therapist: It sounds like acknowledging and confronting these feelings might be uncomfortable for you, which could be a clue to what's driving this anxiety - can you explore what might happen if you allowed yourself to fully experience these unsettling feelings, rather than avoiding them?
Patient: I'm not really sure, but I feel like I'd just have to adapt and figure things out on my own, which is a daunting thought. That's why I've taken steps to prevent those situations from happening in the first place, like setting up Wi-Fi at home and using maps offline on my phone.
Therapist: It's interesting that you've taken proactive steps to prevent these situations, but have you considered what might be the cost of always having a solution to every problem, and whether this constant need for control is actually preventing you from developing other coping strategies that might be more sustainable in the long run?
Patient: I've thought about it, but it's hard for me to imagine not having a quick way to look up information or access Google Maps, it's like a part of my daily routine. I feel like if I'm not able to rely on technology, I'm putting myself at risk of getting lost or making a mistake.
Therapist: It sounds like you're prioritizing the convenience of technology over other potential risks, which might suggest that there's a deeper fear underlying your anxiety about being disconnected from information. Can you explore what you think might happen if you were to get lost or make a mistake in a situation where you couldn't rely on technology?
Patient: I don't know, maybe I'd just have to ask for help or rely on others, which is hard for me to admit, but I guess it's the not knowing what's going to happen that's really unsettling.
Therapist: Let's explore this idea of not knowing what will happen in situations where you can't rely on technology - can you think of a time in your life when you had to ask for help or rely on others, and how did that experience turn out? Was it a positive or negative experience, and what did you learn from it?
Patient: I'm not sure, to be honest, I don't really have any experiences that come to mind where I had to ask for help and everything worked out okay. I guess I just kind of zone out when I think about it.
Therapist: It's interesting that you're struggling to recall a time when relying on others led to a positive outcome, which might suggest that you're carrying some unhelpful assumptions about people's responses to your requests for help - can you explore what you think people's reactions to your requests for help might be?
Patient: I think people might judge me or think I'm incompetent if I ask for help, and that's just not a risk I'm willing to take. It's easier to just have my phone and be able to figure things out on my own, even if it means feeling anxious about being prepared.
Therapist: It's striking that you're assuming people's reactions to your requests for help are judgmental, which may be a self-protective mechanism that's also limiting your ability to form deeper connections with others - can you explore where this assumption might have originated from?
Patient: I've always been someone who's been very self-sufficient and independent, but I guess I never really considered that asking for help doesn't necessarily mean I'm incompetent or weak. It's possible that my anxiety about being offline is just a manifestation of a deeper fear of being vulnerable or dependent on others in some way.

P2: I fled my homeland and now I can’t find belonging anywhere—I feel like I’m nobody. I speak in nostalgic anecdotes about home and press the therapist for historical context, avoiding my present loneliness.
conversation:
Therapist: As I listen to you describe your current struggles, I notice a sense of resignation in your voice, which makes me wonder if there's a part of you that feels like you're stuck in this situation and unsure of how to move forward. Can you tell me more about what's holding you back from taking action or making changes?
Patient: I think about the way my grandmother used to make "ajvar" for family gatherings – it was this perfect blend of roasted peppers and eggplant, a taste of childhood that still transports me back home. Do you know what ajvar is, by the way?
Therapist: It sounds like the memory of your grandmother's ajvar has a strong emotional resonance for you, and I'm guessing it's not just about the taste, but perhaps about the sense of comfort and security it represents. Can you tell me more about what happens for you when you feel like you're in a situation where you're struggling to make changes, do you find yourself craving a similar sense of comfort or familiarity?
Patient: My grandfather used to tell stories about the old days, when the city would host an annual spring festival, and the smell of grilled halloumi cheese would fill the streets. It's funny, but I still associate that smell with hope, even though I'm not even sure what the festival was really like.
Therapist: It sounds like your grandparents' stories and food have become a way for you to connect with a sense of tradition and heritage, which is comforting, but it's also possible that you might be using these memories as a way to avoid confronting the uncertainty and discomfort of your current struggles. Can you think of a time when you had to let go of a beloved tradition or a comforting routine, and how did you experience it?
Patient: My mother used to make these tiny little pierogies on special occasions, and the way the dough would crack when you took a bite was like music to my ears. I still have a faint memory of her teaching me how to knead the dough, but I haven't attempted to make them since we left – the feel of the dough slipping through my fingers reminds me of the fragility of everything I've lost.
Therapist: It sounds like the tactile sensation of kneading the dough has become closely tied to feelings of loss and fragility for you, and I'm curious, is it possible that this emotional connection is preventing you from even trying to make pierogies now, or exploring new traditions and connections with others?
Patient: My mother used to take me to the old fish market by the sea, where the smell of saltwater and fresh seafood would fill the air, and the sound of the fishermen's laughter still echoes in my head – I wonder if they're still there, selling their catch every morning.
Therapist: It sounds like the nostalgic memories of the fish market and the fishermen's laughter are a bittersweet reminder of a sense of freedom and joy that you've lost, and I'm wondering if that sense of loss is also tied to your feelings of being stuck in your current situation. Can you imagine what it would be like to let go of the need to relive those memories and instead, create new experiences and connections that bring you a similar sense of joy and freedom?
Patient: My mother used to take me to the old cinema on Fridays, and the smell of popcorn and worn velvet seats still transports me back to a time when life felt simpler. Do you know if the cinema is still standing, or did it get torn down like so many other parts of our old city?
Therapist: I sense that the cinema is now a nostalgic trigger for you, and I'm wondering if the fact that it might not exist anymore, just like so many other aspects of your old city, adds to your sense of loss and nostalgia. How do you think you would feel if you were to intentionally seek out new places that evoke a similar sense of wonder and enchantment, rather than clinging to the memories of what's been lost?
Patient: The summer festivals in our old neighborhood used to be magical, with the smell of candied chestnuts and the sound of the brass band playing traditional music – I still have a music box that plays the same tune. Do you think it's possible that these nostalgic memories are a way for me to hold onto the idea of a lost youth, rather than confronting the reality of my current life?
Therapist: It sounds like you're beginning to acknowledge the possibility that these nostalgic memories might be serving as a way to avoid confronting the present, but I'm curious, what's the fear that might be holding you back from letting go of that narrative and embracing the uncertainty of creating new experiences? Can you imagine what would happen if you were to approach your current struggles as an opportunity for growth and discovery, rather than a loss of a past you'll never regain?
Patient: The old folk dances at weddings were always such a blur of colors and laughter, but I distinctly remember the way my cousin's aunt would spin to the rhythm of the gaida – it's a skill she still masters to this day, I wonder if she's still teaching young girls how to dance.
Therapist: It sounds like the image of your cousin's aunt dancing is still very vivid for you, and I'm wondering if it's possible that the idea of losing that connection to the past, specifically to the traditional dances, is tied to a deeper fear of losing your sense of cultural identity. What do you think would happen if you were to explore the possibility of learning or relearning one of these traditional dances yourself, rather than relying on the memories of others?
Patient: My mother used to take me to the old family garden, where my grandfather would tell us stories of the medicinal properties of the herbs and plants – the way the scent of wild chamomile would calm the most turbulent of children, like me. Do you think it's possible that these memories are a way for me to hold onto a sense of control, now that I feel like everything else in my life is out of my hands?
Therapist: It sounds like the sense of control you associate with your grandfather's garden is still an important part of your narrative, and I'm wondering if the fact that you don't have a garden or a similar space in your current life might be exacerbating your feelings of being stuck and out of control. Can you imagine what it would be like to create a new sense of connection to nature or a creative outlet that gives you a similar sense of agency and control?
Patient: My mother used to make these intricate wooden ornaments during the winter holidays, and the smell of sandalwood and beeswax still brings back the feeling of being a child surrounded by the warm glow of candles and laughter. I wonder if the intricate patterns on the ornaments hold a secret language that only we knew, a code to a world that's now lost to me.
Therapist: It seems like the intricate patterns on the ornaments have become a nostalgic trigger, but I'm wondering if the idea that they hold a secret language is a way of romanticizing a past that may not be entirely accurate. Can you imagine what would happen if you were to create a new tradition or a new creative outlet that allows you to express yourself in a way that's unique to you, rather than trying to hold onto something that's been lost?
Patient: My grandmother used to make these beautiful, delicate lace doilies that she would teach my sisters how to sew, and the way the threads seemed to dance in the sunlight still gives me a sense of wonder – I wonder if the intricate patterns of the doilies hold a similar secret language that only our family understood.

P2: I obsess over citations and fear I’ll be accused of academic dishonesty. I lecture on referencing styles and journal policies, then shut down when asked how the fear affects my teaching or sleep.
conversation:
Therapist: What brings you to therapy at this time, and what are your hopes for our work together?
Patient: I guess I just feel really anxious about my classes, and I've been noticing that I'm getting defensive with my students whenever they ask me about referencing styles, like it's becoming a sensitive point for me.
Therapist: That sounds like a challenging situation; can you tell me more about what happens just before you feel defensive with your students - is there a specific thought or feeling that triggers this defensiveness for you?
Patient: I start thinking about all the times I got in trouble for plagiarism when I was in school, and how I had to rewrite entire papers from scratch. That old fear of being caught and losing credibility comes flooding back, making me bristle at the idea of anyone questioning my referencing.
Therapist: It sounds like this experience had a profound impact on you, and it's almost as if you're carrying a sense of shame or guilt that's getting triggered in these situations with your students. Can you tell me more about how this shame or guilt shows up for you in the present moment, beyond just feeling defensive?
Patient: It's not just the fear of being caught that's haunting me, but also the fear that others will think I'm not worthy of my position or expertise if I've made mistakes in the past. That shame feels like it's seeping into every interaction with my students, making me question whether I'm really qualified to be teaching them.
Therapist: That sense of shame and self-doubt is having a profound impact on your relationships with your students, and it's interesting that you mention it's affecting your sense of worthiness as a teacher – can you explore with me whether this feeling of not being worthy is a notion you've carried with you for a long time, or if it's something that developed specifically after the plagiarism incidents?
Patient: I think it's been there, lurking beneath the surface, even before the plagiarism incidents, but it's like the experience was a catalyst that brought it to the forefront - now it feels like it's constantly whispering in the back of my mind, questioning my abilities.
Therapist: It sounds like this sense of not being worthy as a teacher and a scholar is a deeply ingrained part of your self-concept, and I'm curious, are you willing to explore the possibility that this self-doubt might be a way of protecting yourself from being vulnerable and truly connecting with your students?
Patient: That's a really insightful question - I think I do use this self-doubt as a shield to keep people from getting too close to me, like I'm afraid if I let my guard down, I'll be exposed as a fake or a charlatan. It's almost like I'm using my expertise in referencing styles as a way to prove to myself and others that I'm still worthy, even if it's at the expense of being able to connect with my students on a more authentic level.
Therapist: It sounds like this self-doubt is not just about protecting your expertise, but also about protecting your sense of identity as a teacher and a person - can you explore with me how this protection might be limiting your ability to show up as your authentic self in the classroom, and what that might mean for your relationships with your students?
Patient: I think I'm so worried that if I let go of this need to control the referencing discussions, I'll somehow lose my authority in the classroom and my students will see me as incompetent - it's like I'm afraid of being seen as vulnerable, rather than strong and capable. That fear is suffocating, and it's making it hard for me to connect with them on a personal level, which is what I want more than anything.
Therapist: It sounds like you're caught in a paradox - you want to connect with your students on a personal level, but your fear of vulnerability is holding you back, making you cling to this need for control over referencing styles as a way to maintain your authority. Can you consider the possibility that your students might be drawn to a teacher who is vulnerable and authentic, rather than one who is trying to control every interaction?
Patient: I think that's a beautiful possibility, but it's hard for me to imagine how I would even begin to let go of this need for control when it feels like it's all that's holding me together in the classroom. I'm terrified of being seen as uncertain or unprepared, like I'm somehow not doing enough to support my students' learning.
Therapist: That sense of fear of being seen as uncertain or unprepared is a huge obstacle for you, and it's interesting that you mention it feels like it's holding you together in the classroom - can you explore with me what would happen if you were to let go of that need for control and perfection, and instead, focus on being present and curious with your students?
Patient: I think if I let go of the need for control, I might find that I'm more present in the moment and able to respond to my students' needs in a way that's more authentic and genuine, rather than just lecturing on referencing styles. It's a terrifying prospect, but also kind of exhilarating to imagine being able to connect with them on a deeper level.
Therapist: It sounds like you're starting to catch a glimpse of the possibility that being vulnerable and authentic might be a more effective way to connect with your students, rather than trying to control every interaction. Can you imagine what it would be like to reframe your relationship with your students from one of authority and control to one of collaboration and mutual learning, and how that might shift your teaching style and interactions with them?
Patient: It's hard for me to imagine a scenario where I wouldn't be "the expert" in the classroom, and I'm worried that if I shift to a more collaborative approach, I'll lose my sense of purpose and identity as a teacher. But I'm starting to wonder if that sense of purpose might be more about my own insecurities than about the actual needs of my students.
Therapist: It sounds like you're beginning to see that your sense of purpose as a teacher might be tied to your own need for validation, rather than the needs of your students; can you explore with me what it would take for you to separate your self-worth from your role as a teacher and find a sense of purpose that's not solely defined by your need for control and expertise?
Patient: I think I've been so focused on proving myself to others that I've forgotten how to find joy in the act of teaching itself, and that's what I really want to get back to - the love of sharing knowledge and watching my students grow.

P2: My little café is drowning in debt. I work 16-hour days but can’t keep up with bills. I present profit-and-loss statements and restructuring plans, then avoid sharing the despair I feel when I see red numbers.
conversation:
Therapist: Can you tell me more about what brings you here today and what you hope to achieve in our sessions together? What's been the most challenging part of your week so far that you'd like to explore further?
Patient: "It's hard to shake this feeling of being trapped, like I'm just running on a treadmill and getting nowhere. I guess what's been really eating at me is the feeling of letting down my employees, who have been shouldering the load right along with me."
Therapist: That sounds incredibly draining, and it's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed by the weight of responsibility. Can you tell me more about what specifically triggers the feeling of "letting down" your employees, is it something they've said or done, or is it more of an internalized sense of guilt?
Patient: It's the way they quietly glance at their watches when we're short-staffed or look at me with a mix of concern and expectation when we can't meet our targets, their unspoken understanding of the pressure I'm under is almost worse than the silence. It's like they're all just holding their breath, waiting for me to find some kind of solution.
Therapist: I notice that you mention your employees' nonverbal cues, such as glancing at their watches, as being particularly impactful – can you explore what you think it is about those specific behaviors that makes you feel so responsible for their expectation of you?
Patient: I think it's because I see myself in them, and their uncertainty makes me feel like I'm failing not just my business, but also the people who have entrusted me with their livelihoods. If they're worried, it's like I'm losing my sense of control and authority as a leader.
Therapist: Can you help me understand, you're saying that their nonverbal cues are not just triggering your sense of responsibility, but also awakening a deep-seated fear of losing control and authority as a leader – could it be that there's a part of you that's still grappling with feelings of inadequacy as a leader, perhaps stemming from past experiences or roles?
Patient: I've always prided myself on being a problem-solver, but lately, it feels like every solution I come up with just leads to another set of problems, and that's making me question if I'm just winging it, rather than truly leading.
Therapist: It sounds like there's a sense of existential dread creeping in, as if you're questioning the very foundation of your leadership and problem-solving abilities. Can you help me explore what would happen if you were to let go of the expectation that you need to be the one with all the answers, and instead, what would it mean to you to be seen as a leader who is vulnerable and open to learning alongside your team?
Patient: That's a really interesting question - I think letting go of the need to have all the answers would mean that I could be more authentic and honest with my team, and maybe even create a sense of safety where we can work together to find solutions rather than me trying to bear the weight alone. It's scary to think about being vulnerable like that, but it's also kind of exhilarating – like it could be a chance for me to rediscover what I'm passionate about and not just trying to keep the business afloat.
Therapist: It seems like the idea of vulnerability is both appealing and terrifying to you, can you tell me more about what specifically is holding you back from embracing this kind of vulnerability, especially given the sense of excitement you mentioned earlier?
Patient: I think what's holding me back is the fear of being perceived as weak or incompetent, both by my employees and by myself – it's like I'm trapped in this perpetual cycle of trying to maintain this image of being a strong leader, rather than being honest about the doubts and fears that are actually driving my decisions.
Therapist: It sounds like this fear of being perceived as weak or incompetent is not just about what others think of you, but also about how you perceive yourself – can you explore what it means to you to be "weak" and how that label intersects with your sense of self-worth? How might your self-concept change if you were to reframe "weakness" as a sign of humanity and humility, rather than a personal failing?
Patient: I think that's a really interesting reframe, and it makes me wonder if my fear of being seen as weak is rooted in the pressure I've put on myself to be a self-sufficient, independent problem-solver, rather than allowing myself to ask for help or admit vulnerability. If I could let go of that expectation, it might free me up to approach challenges with a more collaborative mindset, rather than trying to carry the weight alone.
Therapist: That's a crucial insight, recognizing the pressure you've put on yourself to be self-sufficient – can you explore how this self-imposed expectation might be linked to any past experiences or relationships in your life where you felt supported or unsupported?
Patient: I think growing up, my parents were always so proud of my self-reliance and independence, they often praised me for figuring things out on my own, but looking back, I realize that meant I never really learned how to ask for help or rely on others, and that's a pattern that's carried over into my leadership style. It's interesting to consider how that upbringing has shaped my expectations of myself as a leader.
Therapist: That's a powerful connection to make between your upbringing and your current leadership style – can you explore how you think this realization might change the way you perceive your employees' reliance on you, and whether it might give you a new perspective on the way you're currently shouldering the responsibility for their expectations?
Patient: I think if I can break free from this cycle of self-reliance, I might start to see my employees' reliance on me as a sign of trust rather than a burden, and that would be a huge weight off my shoulders. It's almost like I'm starting to see that my role as a leader isn't about having all the answers, but about creating an environment where others feel safe to contribute and grow alongside me.
Therapist: As you begin to see your employees' reliance on you as a sign of trust, I'm curious, what would be the implications for your communication style, particularly when it comes to delegating tasks and sharing responsibility, might this shift in perspective free you up to be more explicit and clear about your expectations and boundaries, rather than trying to micromanage every detail?
Patient: I think if I were to communicate more clearly about my expectations and boundaries, I might be able to create a sense of clarity and ownership among my team, which could actually help them feel more empowered and motivated to take on more responsibility. By being more explicit, I might also be able to release some of the emotional weight I've been carrying, and focus on supporting them rather than trying to control everything myself.

P2: I’ve been in remission for a year, but each follow-up scan fills me with dread. I detail scan schedules and lab protocols but refuse to talk about the panic in my chest when I hear my appointment time.
conversation:
Therapist: I notice you mentioned earlier that you've been feeling stuck in your current job, but when I asked what specifically is causing that sense of stuckness, you seemed to quickly change the subject. Can you help me understand what's underlying that shift in conversation?
Patient: It's just that I guess I didn't realize I was shifting gears, but when you brought up my job, it made me think of my scans coming up and I started to feel anxious all over again. I think my brain just automatically defaults to avoiding that topic now.
Therapist: It sounds like your brain is indeed avoiding the topic, but I'm curious, what do you think it is specifically about your upcoming scans that's causing such anxiety, and how do you think that's connected to your feelings of being stuck in your job?
Patient: It's like, every time I think about the scans, I start to worry about it not being completely gone, about the cancer coming back. I guess that fear of uncertainty and potential loss of control seeps into other areas of my life, like my job, and makes me feel trapped and stuck.
Therapist: That makes sense, and it sounds like the fear of uncertainty and loss of control is a really pervasive theme in your life right now. Can you help me understand what that sense of control means to you, and what does it feel like when you're not in control?
Patient: It feels like when I'm not in control, everything is more chaotic and unpredictable, and I feel like I'm just along for the ride, powerless to change the outcome. It's like I'm constantly waiting for the other shoe to drop, and that's exhausting.
Therapist: That sounds like a really intense sense of vulnerability and powerlessness - it's almost as if you're describing a sense of being at the mercy of external forces. Can you think of any times in your life when you've felt a sense of control or agency that's helped you feel more grounded, even in the face of uncertainty or unpredictability?
Patient: When I was in treatment, I think the sense of control came from having a clear plan and knowing exactly what to expect each day - it was like having a framework that I could rely on, even when everything else felt uncertain. But now that I'm in remission, I'm not sure what that framework is anymore, and that's what's been making me feel so ungrounded.
Therapist: It sounds like you're experiencing a sense of disorientation without that clear plan, and I'm curious, is it possible that you're holding onto the idea that you need to find a new framework or structure in order to feel in control, rather than exploring other sources of agency or resilience that might be emerging in your life?
Patient: I think what you're saying makes sense, but for me, it's hard to shake the feeling that without that treatment plan, I'm somehow failing at taking care of myself, like I'm not doing enough to stay healthy. It's like I'm constantly wondering if I'm doing enough to prevent the cancer from coming back.
Therapist: I want to gently challenge this idea that you're failing at taking care of yourself; can you explore with me what it would mean for you to let go of the notion that you're solely responsible for preventing the cancer from coming back, and how that might shift your sense of control?
Patient: I think if I could let go of the responsibility of preventing the cancer from coming back, it would mean that I could finally allow myself to feel hopeful and present in my life, rather than constantly living in a state of vigilance. But it's hard to imagine what that feels like, like I'm letting my guard down and leaving myself open to being hurt again.
Therapist: It sounds like you're describing a trade-off between living in a state of vigilance and letting go, but I'd like to explore with you, what if that vigilance is actually a way of avoiding feelings of uncertainty and vulnerability that are associated with being in remission, rather than an effective way of preventing the cancer from coming back? Can you think of any moments when you've allowed yourself to let your guard down and felt okay, even if only for a moment, without the cancer coming back as a result?
Patient: It feels like when I do let my guard down and allow myself to feel vulnerable, it's almost like my brain tries to convince me that I'm being foolish or reckless for doing so, and that I'm putting myself at risk of getting hurt again. I think that's part of why it's hard for me to fully let go of the vigilance, because my mind is wired to believe that if I'm not constantly on high alert, I'm somehow inviting disaster.
Therapist: That makes sense, it sounds like your brain is caught in a cycle of self-protection, where the fear of vulnerability is actually preventing you from experiencing the very thing you're longing for - a sense of hope and presence in your life. Can you imagine what it would be like to gently confront that inner critic that's telling you you're being foolish or reckless for letting your guard down, and what might happen if you were to respond to it in a more compassionate and curious way?
Patient: I feel like my inner critic is constantly whispering that I'm being irresponsible and lazy if I don't stay vigilant, but it's hard to silence it when it feels like the stakes are so high. It's like, what if this time it's not just anxiety, but my body is actually trying to tell me something, and I'm missing it because I'm too busy trying to stay safe.
Therapist: That's a really astute observation about your inner critic, and I'm curious, do you think there's a part of you that's afraid that if you listen to your body and pay attention to your sensations, you might actually be tuning into a signal that's been there all along, but you've been ignoring because it's uncomfortable?
Patient: I think that's a scary possibility, but at the same time, it's a relief to consider that maybe this anxiety isn't just about being vigilant, but about something more nuanced, something my body is trying to communicate to me. It's like I've been so focused on preventing the cancer from coming back that I haven't allowed myself to truly listen to what my body is telling me about its own needs and boundaries.
Therapist: Let's explore this idea of listening to your body's needs and boundaries more deeply - can you imagine what that might look like in a daily or weekly practice, and how you might start to tune in to the subtle cues that your body is giving you? What would be the first step you'd take to start listening to your body in this way?
Patient: I think the first step would be to start paying attention to my physical sensations during my daily activities, like when I'm eating or taking a walk, and notice if there are any areas of tension or discomfort that could be indicating my body's needs. Maybe I could start by taking a few deep breaths and asking myself, "What am I feeling right now?"
